thread.title: Raines eyes No. 1 spot after sloppy win over First Coast
thread.title_full: Raines eyes No. 1 spot after sloppy win over First Coast

author: Justin Barney
title: Raines eyes No. 1 spot after sloppy win over First Coast
text:
Raines eyes No. 1 spot after sloppy win over First Coast 
By Justin Barney Sat, Oct 10, 2015 @ 12:28 am | updated Sat, Oct 10, 2015 @ 4:11 am 
Deran Wiley couldn’t wait for Monday. 
The Raines football coach was heading back to the Vikings locker room on Friday night, ready to tear into the film and find out just where the problems are at that need fixing. 
The Vikings are likely headed for the No. 1 ranking in Class 4A following their 26-15 win over rival First Coast — and Bolles’ loss to Columbia — but there was more nitpicking going on than celebrating. 
Raines, ranked No. 2 in Class 4A and third in the Times-Union’s Power Poll, believed it was miles ahead of the reeling Buccaneers and prepared to make a statement to the area and the rest of the state. 
Instead, a fast start gave way to an uneven finish and a late night for Wiley. 
“We have just got to play better,” he said. “We are athletic and talented enough. We just have to learn how to be better from the neck up. No disrespect to them, but we are better than that [score].” 
Raines had been the only dent in the Buccaneers’ armor over the last five regular seasons, handing First Coast (1-5) its lone defeat — 18-10 in OT in 2013 — in a 48-1 run for the Buccaneers. 
Included in that was a savage, 62-7 beating last year and an overwhelming feeling that the Vikings (6-0), owners of the area’s most vicious defense, would repay the favor this time. 
It wound up nothing of the sort. 
Raines went ahead 14-0 quick on a pair of Alex Rutledge touchdowns and then widened it to 20-0 midway through the third quarter on a Willie Wright 65-yard punt return for a score. But the expected breakaway to the finish, the running clock, the return beating, never materialized. 
Penalties were a glaring issue, a dreadful 16 of them for 155 yards, with four of those coming on fourth down to keep Buccaneers drives going. 
“We had too many yards in penalties,” said Rutledge, who had 174 yards rushing on 16 carries and scored on runs of 4, 29 and 53 yards. 
“We need all those yards going forward instead of backwards. We’ll go back to the drawing board. Coach said he’s got something for us for all those penalties.” 
Super 11 selection Kevin Stepherson was the other problem for the Vikings. 
He found his way through the Raines’ defense throughout the game, scoring more in one half than the Vikings had allowed in five full previous games combined (10). 
Stepherson took a kickoff back 74 yards for a touchdown and helped turn a Vikings turnover into points on a 56-yard touchdown pass from Jevaro Hardy, trimming a Raines lead to 26-13 in the fourth quarter. The Buccaneers added a safety, too. 
“They’ve got a good football team. I think they’ve got to make a few corrections to make a run in the state playoffs, but they outplayed us tonight,” said First Coast coach Marty Lee. 
“We’ve got some things to clean up. We got three [district] games the rest of the season that we’ve got to worry about. It is what it is and that’s high school football.” 
Raines and its top-rated defense held First Coast to 30 rushing yards on 29 carries and had an interception by Davonte Lawrence on a trick play by Stepherson. Hardy finished 12-of-25 for 170 yards and a score. 
The Vikings defense also stopped two deep drives by the Buccaneers, one that stalled at the Raines 4 and the other at the 28, both on downs.
